title: Puzzle Competition
question_text:
In a puzzle competition, competitors are given a different puzzle to solve for each round.
The first round presents a puzzle known to be normally distributed with a solution time of $\mu = 3\text{ minutes}$ and $\sigma=0.4\text{ minutes}$. The fastest $20\%$ of competitors advance to the next round.
To the nearest tenth of a minute, what cutoff score will advance a competitor to the next round?
solution:

First, note that the fastest solution times will be less than the mean solution time of $3\text{ minutes}$, so the answer should be a value below $3$. This is important: the fastest speeds would be the lowest times.

To solve this problem, use either a table of standard normal probabilities or the “inverse normal” function on a calculator.

This problem presents a probability of $20\%$, so look in the body of the table, and you will find a $z$-value closest to $-0.84$ corresponding to an area of $0.20$ as shown in the image above.

Now use the conversion formula:

$$z = \dfrac{(X-\mu)}{\sigma}$$

...to find the cutoff score.

$$-0.84 =\dfrac{ (X-3)}{0.4}$$

$$(-.84)(0.4) = X-3$$

$$-0.336 = X-3$$

$$2.66=X$$

So $X$ is $3-0.336$, or $2.66$, which rounds to $2.7$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'B'.
